head.ce:title: Influence of dietary supplementation with flaxseed and lactobacilli on the cells of local innate immunity response in the jejunal mucosa in piglets after weaning

ce:affiliation.ce:label: a
ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Department of Histology and Embryology, Faculty of Medicine, Pavel Jozef Safarik University, Kosice , Slovak Republic

ce:affiliation.ce:label: b
ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: International Clinical Research Center, St. Anne’s University Hospital and Masaryk University, Brno , Czech Republic

sa:affiliation.sa:organization: International Clinical Research Center, St. Anne’s University Hospital and Masaryk University

ce:affiliation.ce:label: c
ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Clinica Medica I, Fondazione IRCCS Policlinico San Matteo, Universita degli Studi di Pavia, Pavia , Italy

ce:affiliation.ce:label: d
ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Department of Microbiology and Immunology, University of Veterinary Medicine and Pharmacy, Kosice , Slovak Republic

sa:affiliation.sa:organization: University of Veterinary Medicine and Pharmacy

ce:correspondence.ce:text: Corresponding author at: International Clinical Research Center, St. Anne’s University Hospital and Masaryk University, Pekarska 53, 656 91 Brno, Czech Republic.

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para:
A histological study was designed to determine the influence of flaxseed and/or lactobacilli inclusion in the diet of piglets from 10 days before to 21 days after weaning. The selected inflammatory cell population incidence in the piglet jejunal mucosa was investigated. Significantly higher numbers of myeloperoxidase-positive ( P
<
0.01) and CD163-positive ( P
<
0.001) cells in the jejunal mucosa were recorded on the weaning day and for 7 days after ( P
<
0.001 and P
<
0.01, respectively) in the flaxseed group compared with the basal diet. The number of intraepithelial lymphocytes was also significantly increased until 3 days after weaning ( P
<
0.001). A prolonged significant increase in the myeloperoxidase-positive cells and intraepithelial lymphocyte numbers in the flaxseed
+
lactobacilli group was detected. In contrast, the number of CD163-positive cells in the flaxseed
+
lactobacilli group was significantly lower on the day of weaning ( P
<
0.05) and 3 days after ( P
<
0.01). The same effect was observed in the group with lactobacilli alone during the first 3 days after weaning ( P
<
0.05 and P
<
0.01, respectively) and these findings indicate down-regulation of CD163 expression in the jejunal mucosa by lactobacilli . The presence of lactobacilli in the diet had a stimulatory effect on goblet cell quantity in the epithelium ( P
<
0.001) and a distinct 50% reduction in the flaxseed group ( P
<
0.01) compared with the basal diet was observed on the weaning day. A significant increase in myeloperoxidase-positive cell number in the jejunal mucosa in the flaxseed
+
lactobacilli group was the only significant difference ( P
<
0.05 and P
<
0.01, respectively) found 21 days after weaning in comparison with all the other groups, indicating the pro-inflammatory effect of this feed additive combination. We conclude that dietary supplementation with flaxseed and lactobacilli on the cells of local innate immunity response in the jejunal mucosa in piglets after weaning might be linked with significant anti-inflammatory effects in the jejunal mucosa.

ce:section.ce:para: At weaning, piglets are subjected to many stressful circumstances associated with their change of environment, separation from the mothers, transport, and general replacement of fluid milk nutrition by solid food with a different composition and nutrient value. The complexes of these social, environmental and dietary stresses interfere with gut development and adaptation and are definitely responsible for maldigestion, malabsorption, shift in gut microflora, poor performance and diarrhoea in piglets after weaning (PW) ( Verdonk, 2006 ). The pathophysiological base of all these disorders is closely connected with the inflammatory response of the intestinal mucosa.

The intestinal surface is covered by a protective mucous layer which represents the front line of innate host defence. The goblet cells (GC), which reside throughout the length of the intestine within the intestinal epithelial layer, are responsible for the production and maintenance of the mucous layer coating the gastrointestinal tract. Another special cell type present in the epithelium that is involved in the immunological interrelations are the intraepithelial lymphocytes (IEL), which make up the first immune cell line of defence in the intestine ( Beagley and Husband, 1998 ). The majority of these cells are CD8-positive T cells ( Ishikawa et al., 2007 ). Their specific function is not clear, but it has been suggested that they may play a variety of roles, such as immunoregulation and promoting epithelial damage repair ( Shen, 2009 ). Among the connective tissue cells involved in the innate immunity inflammatory processes, a remarkable position is held by polymorphonuclear leukocytes and tissue macrophages. The tissue myeloperoxidase (MPO) activity is one of the earliest consequences of neutrophil inflammation ( Nauseef, 2007 ), while in the absence of inflammation, MPO is not found in the extravascular tissue. The plasma membrane glycoprotein CD163, a member of the scavenger receptor cysteine-rich superfamily class B, is highly expressed on resident tissue macrophages and to a lesser extent on monocytes ( Fabriek et al., 2005 ). The evaluation of MPO-positivity, CD163-positivity and numbers of IEL and GC was used in this study to assess the intensity of the inflammatory response. Many nutritional strategies are arranged to prevent economic losses connected with malnutrition of piglets PW. From a dietary point of view, various biologically active substances, e.g., probiotics, prebiotics, non-specific substrates, plant extracts, organic acids or polyunsaturated fatty acids, are included in the diet of piglets around weaning to maintain intestinal homoeostasis ( Bomba et al., 2006). The aim of our experimental study was to analyse changes in the inflammatory cell populations present in the mucosa, which reflect the health status and the level of local innate immunity of the intestine and have a potential influence on diarrhoeic syndrome progress. The selected cell populations were recorded from the day of weaning (WD) to 21 days PW in piglets. Our objectives were: (1) to evaluate changes in the mucous-producing GC number in the jejunal epithelium; (2) to analyse the mucosal cells participating in the inflammatory response – IEL, MPO-positive cells and CD163-positive cells; (3) to evaluate the influence of biologically active substances on these processes – lactobacilli and/or flaxseed as a source of polyunsaturated fatty acids (n-3 PUFA); (4) to compare the differences between the experimental groups with different diets at the same time period as well as the time-dependent changes in the individual groups during 21 days PW.

The State Veterinary and Food Administration of the Slovak Republic approved the experimental protocol number 2108/07-221 and the animals were handled and sacrificed in a humane manner in accordance with the guidelines established by the respective commission.

The Lactobacillus probiotic strains were isolated at University of Veterinary Medicine and Pharmacy, Kosice, Slovakia. The Lactobacillus plantarum – Biocenol™; LP96 (CCM 7512) strain was selected from the gut content of a healthy suckling piglet and Lactobacillus fermentum – Biocenol™; LF99 (CCM 7514) was isolated from the gastrointestinal tract of an adult chicken. Cheddar cheese was used as a vehicle for probiotic strains at 1 ×
10 9
CFU/g of cheese. The control cheese did not contain probiotic strains.

The experiment was carried out on 88 clinically healthy piglets (cross-bred -
Yorkshire ×
Pietrain). The piglets were housed in typical indoor pens and were divided into four groups: control group S (control cheese
+
sunflower oil) 19 piglets; group SL (probiotic cheeses
+
sunflower oil) 23 piglets; group F (control cheese
+
whole crushed flaxseed) 23 piglets; group FL (probiotic cheeses
+
whole crushed flaxseed) 23 piglets.

The animals were fed Os-02 (Spisske kemne zmesi, Spisske Vlachy, Slovak Republic) feed mixture for early piglet weaning. The basal diet was supplemented with whole crushed flaxseed cultivar Flanders (Agrola Kozusice, Czech Republic): 100
g flaxseed (i.e., 45.8
g lipids)/1
kg basal diet for the F and FL groups and control oil: 45.8
g sunflower oil/1
kg basal diet for the S and SL groups. Table 1
gives the fatty acid profile of flaxseed, sunflower oil and the basal diet.

The piglets were weaned at the age of 28 days. Ten days before WD and 21 days PW the experimental piglets in groups SL and FL were supplied with probiotic cheeses daily (4
g/animal/day for each cheese). Piglets in the S and F groups were supplied with control cheese at a dose of 8
g/animal/day. The probiotic and control cheeses were supplied to piglets once a day (individually in the morning) in grated form on the surface of the feed. The animals liked the cheese and consumed it instantaneously. In the same period the animals had ad libitum access to water and feed supplemented with whole crushed flaxseed or sunflower oil.

The pigs in all groups were sacrificed using T61 (Intervet International B.V., Boxmeer, The Netherlands, dose: 0.3 ml/kg body weight) intracardially on WD (28-day-old piglets) and on Days 3, 7 and 21 PW. The gastrointestinal tract was immediately removed from the sacrificed piglets. Small intestine samples (jejunum) 1–2
cm long were taken 10
cm from the Ligament of Trietz, washed with cold saline and fixed in 4% paraformaldehyde. The tissues were then embedded in paraffin wax, cut into 4–5 μm sections, and mounted. After deparaffinisation, the tissues were stained with haematoxylin–eosin (HE) for histological examination.

For immunohistochemistry, wax embedded sections (4–5 μm thick) were deparaffinised and rehydrated. Endogenous peroxidase activity was blocked with 3% H 2 O 2 with methanol. Pre-treatment was performed in a microwave oven at 600
W for 15
min in 0.01 M citrate buffer at pH 6.0. A primary anti-MPO rabbit polyclonal antibody (RB-373-A0; 1:100; Thermo Scientific, Waltham, MA, USA), and a primary anti-CD163 rabbit clonal antibody (DB 045-0.5; 1:100; DB-Biotech, Kosice, Slovakia) were used. Primary antibodies were labelled using a two-stage indirect immunoperoxidase technique. Primary antibodies were applied at the appropriate titre ( Table 2
). Anti-mouse IgG (H
+
L)/anti-rabbit IgG (H
+ L) was used for detection of MPO-positive cells (TL-015-HDS; Thermo Scientific-Ultra Vision LPValue Detection System HRP Polymer & DAB Plus Chromogen; Thermo Scientific, Waltham, MA, USA). Biotinylated secondary goat anti-mouse IgG/goat anti-rabbit IgG (DAB150; Millipore IHC Select® Immunoperoxidase Secondary Detection System; Millipore Bioscience Research Reagents, Billerica, MA, USA) was used for detection of a CD163-positive cell population. Positive cells were visualised with diaminobenzidine (DAB) (Sigma–Aldrich, St. Louis, MO, USA) and counterstained with Mayer’s haematoxylin ( Fig. 1
a,b). Omission of the primary antibodies was considered as the negative control.

The quantity of IEL was determined in 10 intestinal villi and corresponding crypts in each sample using a magnification 1000×. The IEL population present in the jejunal epithelium was detected using routine HE staining ( Fig. 1 c).

The population of GC present in the intestinal mucosa was detected using the alcian blue histochemical staining method. Alcian blue 8GX solution (pH 2.5) (Sigma–Aldrich, St. Louis, MO, USA) stains both sulphated and carboxylated acid mucopolysaccharides and sulphated and carboxylated sialomucins (glycoproteins). Excessive amounts of non-sulphated acidic mucosubstances were seen in the cytoplasm of secretory GC. Strongly acidic mucosubstances in the cytoplasm were stained blue, while nuclei were counterstained pink to red using neutral red stain. Alcian blue/neutral red stained tissues were acquired and the number of alcian blue positive GC was determined in 10 intestinal villi in each sample ( Fig. 1 d).

The tissue sections were examined and photographed using an Olympus BX50 light microscope with an Olympus SP350 camera (Olympus, Tokyo, Japan) and were evaluated in a blinded study by two independent histologists.

The statistical analysis was performed using GraphPad InStat version 3.01 (GraphPad Software, San Diego, CA, USA). The results were determined using one-way ANOVA with a multiple comparison Tukey–Kramer post hoc test. All the results are expressed as mean ±
SEM. P values less than 0.05 were considered significant.

The piglets in the groups with n-3 PUFA in the diet showed a significantly higher amount of MPO-positive cells in the jejunal samples ( Table 3
) than those in the corresponding control S and SL groups on WD ( P
<
0.01 and P
<
0.001, respectively). Similar significant results both 3 and 7 days PW were found. The MPO-positive cells in the samples taken 21 days PW were significantly the most numerous in the FL group, even significantly more numerous than in the corresponding F group ( P
<
0.01 vs. both S and SL groups; P
<
0.05 vs. F group). A significant time-dependent increase in MPO activity ( Fig. 2
) was detected on Days 3 and 7 in the SL group ( vs. WD P
<
0.05 and P
<
0.01, respectively). Conversely, a significant decrease of the same on Day 21 PW in the F group was found ( vs. WD P
<
0.01).

The IEL numbers ( Table 4
) in both flaxseed groups (F and FL) were significantly higher than those in the sunflower groups (S, SL) on WD ( P
<
0.05 and P
<
0.001, respectively). Similarly, higher numbers 3 days PW in the F group and 7 days ( P
<
0.001 both) PW in the FL group were observed. Approximately the same values were found in all groups 21 days PW. In the SL group a significant increase in IEL at all time periods comparing to WD ( Fig. 3
) was found ( P
<
0.01 and P
<
0.001, respectively). The increase in IEL population quantity in the S group started later, after Day 7 PW ( P
<
0.01).

The most numerous CD163-positive population ( Table 5
) was present in the F group in the first 7 days PW ( vs . S, L and FL groups P
<
0.001and P
<
0.01, respectively). The SL and FL groups, with lactobacilli in the diet, revealed significantly lower CD163-positivity in comparison with the basal diet group both on WD ( P
<
0.05) and 3 days later ( P
<
0.01). Those groups in the time-dependent comparison showed an increase in CD163 immunoreactivity at Day 7 PW ( P
<
0.05 and P
<
0.01, respectively) compared to the results found in the samples taken 3 days PW. The decrease in CD163-positive population in the F group started after Day 7 PW ( P
<
0.01), and at Day 21 PW the value measured showed no significant difference in comparison with all the other groups ( Fig. 4
).

The smallest number of GC in F group during the first week PW was noticed. A significant reduction of that in the F group in comparison with S ( P
<
0.01) and both L and FL groups ( P
<
0.001) on WD was evident ( Table 6
). The maximal GC number in the SL group on WD was observed ( P
<
0.001 vs . S and F; P
<
0.05 vs . FL). A significant increase in GC number at Day 21 PW was detected ( P
<
0.01) in the F group compared to all previous sampling within this group ( Fig. 5
). In the L group, a significant decrease in GC number at Days 3 and 7 was observed ( vs. WD P
<
0.001 both) and at 21 days PW the number was significantly increased ( P
<
0.01) in comparison with Day 7 PW. At 21 days PW, no differences in GC quantity between the groups were noticed.

The fatty acid composition of the plasma membrane of inflammatory and immune cells is sensitive to change according to the fatty acid composition of the diet. In particular, the proportion of different types of PUFA in these cells is readily changed, and this provides a link between dietary PUFA intake, inflammation and immunity ( Calder, 2001 ). While n-6 PUFA activates the immune system and acts in a more pro-inflammatory way, n-3 PUFA has a significant anti-inflammatory effect ( Calder, 2013; Yaqoob, 2004). Flaxseed oil (FO) is the main component of flaxseed and one of the world’s most important vegetable sources of α-linolenic acid. As a nutritionally essential PUFA, it can act as the precursor of longer chain n-3 PUFA, compete with linoleic acid (n-6 PUFA) or can directly interact with ion channels and nuclear receptors, and thus may exert various biological functions in the body, including inflammation ( Barcelo-Coblijn and Murphy, 2009; Calder, 2013). However, since α-linolenic acid is highly susceptible to oxidation, addition of FO to the diet leads to a significantly higher tendency toward plasma lipid peroxidation ( Trebusak et al., 2011 ), which may have an adverse effect. Moreover, a few studies have described different or contradictory n-3 PUFA effects depending on physiological, nutritional or environmental conditions. In some experimental studies it was shown that a large dietary intake of n-3 PUFA could even exacerbate colitis ( Hegazi et al., 2006; Matsunaga et al., 2008 ). Maternal FO supplementation increased colonic mRNA abundance of pro-inflammatory cytokines in weaned pigs ( Leonard et al., 2012 ).

It is known that inclusion of high doses of n-3 PUFA may increase oxidative damage owing to the number of unsaturated double bonds. The contradictory results about pro-inflammatory response might be explained by different antioxidant requirements promoted by stress conditions, since PUFA are more sensitive to oxidative stress than saturated fats ( Carroll and Forsberg, 2007 ). Weaning undoubtedly presents a complex of very strong stressful factors for piglets. Caroprese et al. (2009) demonstrated that feed supplementation of n-3 PUFA can enhance the immune response of dairy cows exposed to high ambient temperatures acting as a stressful factor. During intestinal inflammation, resident monocytes contribute to the recruitment of neutrophils through production of macrophage-derived chemokines. Activated neutrophils are reported to be the main source of superoxide radicals ( Duilio et al., 2001 ). Dismutation of superoxide catalysed by the MPO released from the azurophilic granules of neutrophils results in synthesis of hydrogen peroxide, hydroxyl radicals and hypochlorous acid ( Kaminski et al., 2002 ). The piglets in both the groups with n-3 fatty acids in their diet (F and FL) showed significantly higher MPO activity in the jejunal samples than those in the corresponding control S and SL groups on WD, 3 and 7 days PW, respectively. These data confirm the inflammation-causing effects of n-3 PUFA in jejunal mucosa, probably elicited by oxidative damage. Our results are supported by a study in gnotobiotic piglets fed with flaxseed, in which the up-regulation of pro-inflammatory chemokine IL-8 was observed ( Chytilova et al., 2013 ). IL-8 is known as a neutrophil chemotactic factor and induces phagocytosis ( Takashiba et al., 1992 ).

In our study, the up-regulation of MPO activity was not recorded in piglets with flaxseed alone in the diet 21 days PW, but in the group with lactobacilli combined with flaxseed the MPO-positive cell number was significantly higher than in all the other groups that day. Lactobacilli alone had no significant effect on MPO-positivity in any time period. In contrast, addition of lactobacilli to the diet of piglets induced down-regulation of CD163-positive cells on WD, as well as 3 days PW, in both the L and FL groups. On the other hand, flaxseed alone had a stimulatory effect on the amount of CD163-positive cells from WD to at least 7 days PW. Likewise, up-regulation of CD163 has been documented in many inflammatory pathologies ( Baeten et al., 2002; Sugaya et al., 2012; Fuentes-Duculan et al., 2010 ). CD163 identifies a specific subset of alternatively activated macrophages ( Gordon, 2003 ) which exert anti-inflammatory effects ( Kristiansen et al., 2001 ) and CD163-expressing macrophages constitute the predominant macrophage population during the late or resolution phase of many inflammatory reactions. CD163 expression is strongly induced by anti-inflammatory mediators, such as glucocorticoids and IL-10 ( Morganelli and Guyre, 1988; Sulahian et al., 2000 ). More recently, it has been demonstrated that CD163 can also bind both Gram-negative and Gram-positive bacteria and activate a number of intracellular events that lead to the production of pro-inflammatory cytokines ( Fabriek et al., 2009 ). Therefore, it is plausible that CD163 may play a dual role in the control of immune responses, perhaps depending on the microenvironment in which CD163-expressing cells are located ( Franze et al., 2013 ).

The intestinal epithelium is covered by a protective mucous layer which represents the front line of innate host defence. Goblet cells synthesise secretory mucin glycoproteins representing a major component of the mucous and bioactive molecules such as epithelial membrane-bound mucins, which represent a cell surface protective barrier ( Kim and Ho 2010 ). In addition, they contribute to epithelial restitution, facilitate cell migration and block apoptosis by producing intestinal trefoil factor peptides ( Taupin and Podolsky 2003; Kjellev 2009 ). The relatively high resistance of GC to injury and the production of trefoil factor peptides with direct influence on the epithelial restitution make GC a very important part of the intestinal healing process ( Toth et al., 2012). In the present study, the inclusion of flaxseed in the piglets’ diet around weaning led to a significant decrease in the GC population in the jejunum. In contrast, the presence of lactobacilli in the FL and SL groups caused a significant increase in the GC population, although the number in the flaxseed
+
lactobacilli group was significantly lower than in the group with lactobacilli alone. Our results showed that including lactobacilli increases the GC number in the jejunum of piglets at weaning, while inclusion of the n-3 rich flaxseed diet leads to a decrease in GC number. Nieto et al. (2002) showed that different sources of fatty acids alter the type of mucins in GC. In contrast to our results, they found more GC with mature inner mucin granules in rats with experimental ulcerative colitis fed with fish oil, a source of n-3 PUFA. Our results showing increased GC number in groups with lactobacilli in the diet confirm recently published data about regulation of intestinal epithelial cell differentiation by colonic bacteria. Goblet cells derive from intestinal stem cells located in the lower part of the crypts. Becker et al. (2013) showed the regulatory effect of bacteria on epithelial cell differentiation by transcription factors Hath1 and KLF4 known to direct progenitor cells towards GC. In addition, they ascertained that the induction of mucin Muc1 and defensin HBD2 production seems to be triggered directly by bacteria.

In the intestinal epithelium, IEL are in close contact with enterocytes. They are numerous, especially in the small intestine, and can be activated in response to several pathological conditions ( Kapp et al., 2004 ). IEL and their cytokines play an important role in the regulation of gut immune response and take part in gut immune barrier function. Particularly, multiple studies have shown that an increase in IEL numbers is associated with coeliac disease, which allows for the diagnosis to be made before the architectural changes are appreciated ( Marsh and Crowe, 1995 ). Pleskovic et al. (2001) demonstrated that combined experimental radiotherapy and chemotherapy caused loss of enterocytes/colonocytes and IEL early after the therapy in dogs. These morphological changes in the colon mucosa might be the earliest changes leading to disruption of the mucosal barrier, malabsorption syndrome, stenosis, inflammation and other complications resulting from the radiotherapy and chemotherapy. PUFA can alter T cell activation and signalling by altering the lateral organisation of the membrane bilayer, and they can alter antigen presentation through the major histocompatibility complex class I and II specific changes in the plasmalemma and endomembrane ( Shaikh and Edidin, 2007 ). The inclusion of lactobacilli in the piglets’ diet caused a significant decrease in IEL numbers on WD, although from 3 days PW a significant increase in the same began. In the flaxseed groups, both alone and combined with lactobacilli , the opposite effect was observed with a longer duration of up to 7 days PW. At 3 weeks PW no differences were found between the experimental groups and the basal diet group.

The literature concerning the effects of n-3 PUFA on inflammation is controversial. However, the pro-inflammatory effect of n-3 PUFA is documented in various conditions and they may change the balance between pro-inflammatory and anti-inflammatory cytokines in an inflammatory direction, possibly related to the pro-oxidative effects of these fatty acids ( Holm et al., 2001 ).

In conclusion, this study demonstrated the immunomodulatory character of flaxseed and lactobacilli on IEL, GC, MPO-positive and CD163-positive cell populations in jejunal mucosa and their time-dependent changes. The higher numbers of MPO-positive cells, IEL and CD163-positive cells were recorded on WD and during the first week PW in the flaxseed group, and an even stronger increase in MPO-positivity and IEL in combination with lactobacilli was detected. The oxidation due to the number of unsaturated double bonds in n-3 PUFA could potentially be the reason for inflammatory cell accumulation. In contrast, the number of CD163-positive cells in the lactobacilli
+
flaxseed group was significantly lower than in the basal diet group. The same effect was observed in the group with lactobacilli alone in the first 3 days PW, and these findings indicate the down-regulation of CD163 expression in jejunal mucosa by lactobacilli . The presence of lactobacilli in the diet had a stimulatory effect on GC quantity in the epithelial layer. The distinct 50% reduction in the flaxseed group in comparison with the basal diet could be induced by massive cell degranulation and secretory exhaustion. The effects seem to be age-dependent, because the differences between various diet groups 21 days PW were not significant, due probably to the attenuated stress of animals further PW and with more mature intestinal morphology. The significant increase in MPO-positive cell number in the jejunal mucosa in the flaxseed
+
lactobacilli group in comparison with the basal and lactobacilli diet groups at all time periods was the only constantly present difference, indicating the pro-inflammatory effect of the combined diet.

ce:acknowledgment.ce:para:
This study was supported by the grant of European Regional Development Fund – Project FNUSA-ICRC
(No. CZ.1.05/1.1.00/02.0123), and project SK0021, co-financing through the European Economic area financial mechanism, the Norwegian financial mechanism and the state budget of the Slovak Republic. We gratefully acknowledge the material and technical assistance of A. Hantke, L. Haberova, M. Hnat and A. Hornakova.

sb:title.sb:maintitle: Fatty acids and the immune system: from basic science to clinical applications
